newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: Colombo stocks end higher on tea, blue chip gains.
newsitem.headline: Colombo stocks end higher on tea, blue chip gains.

text.p: Foreign buying of blue chips and strength of tea shares pushed Sri Lankan stocks to a higher close on Tuesday, brokers said.
Blue chip gains helped the all share index end 2.03 points higher at 564.29. Hayleys rose five rupees to 190, JKH 75 cents to 172 rupees and National Development Bank one rupee to 194.
"Foreigners bought blue chips. Due to the good performance of the tea industry, local investors collected plantation shares," said Thikshan Arulampalam of Lanka Securities.
Kegalle Plantations rose 2.50 rupees to 20 and Kelani Valley one to 22.

The plantation sector is now trading at under five times annualised earnings, Arulampalam said. Investors also sought Tea Smallholder Factories and Merchant Bank, which have high exposures to plantations, brokers said.
Turnover was an active 33 million rupees, supported by foreign buying of 155,000 John Keells Holdings.
Commercial Bank downwardly revised prices for its one-for-four rights announced in June after the market prices approached the rights prices, stock exchange officials said.
The price of voting shares were cut to 80 rupees from 100, and a non-voting to 70 from 85. - Prithi Kodagoda (941) 434319
